text:
Welcome to Managing Through
Crisis, where Harvard Business

School faculty
share their insights

about how to lead yourself and
others in challenging times.

Today, I'm very happy to
welcome Professor Sandra

Sucher, an expert on
trust and the author

of The Power of Trust,
How Companies Build It,
Lose It, Regain It.
Welcome, Sandra.
Oh, thanks so much.

I'm just going to set a little
bit of context for us here.

The 2021 Edelman
Trust Barometer,

which I know you're
familiar with,

surveyed 33,000
people in 28 countries

to gauge their trust in
governments, NGOs, business,

and the media, and that revealed
that people don't know where

or who to turn to for
reliable information.

A majority of the
respondents believe

that leaders and
journalists are purposely
trying to mislead people.

And the study finds that
we are in the midst of what
they're calling an infodemic.
Yeah.

Somewhat surprisingly,
the study showed

that business is the most
trusted institution among those

that they studied and
the only institution seen
as both ethical and competent.

So my first question to you is,
why doesn't it feel that way?

It doesn't feel like that at
all from where I'm standing.
Yeah.

So with respect to Edelman,
here's what they do.

They survey and compare people's
trust in institutions, right,

and so they're
comparing whether or not

you, relatively speaking,
trust business more, government
more, NGOs, or the media.

And so they give you
scores for those,

and then we get to
see who's doing well.

And the trend of business
actually doing pretty well

has been established
for a couple of years.

And so I think the
discrepancy that you

feel is something around the
difference between what happens

when you fill out a survey,
and I'm asked to think

about these various
institutions and how they're

doing in society, and then
when you think about the way

those same institutions
affect your life.
Yeah.

And so for business,
compared with, honestly,

the other three, we touch
people in all different ways.

We're customers, we're
employees, we're shareholders.

We're members of communities
where people do business.

And so, on that daily
lived experience front,

I think that from
a trust standpoint,

we tend to look at how
companies' actions affect us
and the people we care about.

And in that regard, we
probably have a different kind

of a calculus if
something has gone south.

You've looked at
so many companies

with this topic
of trust in mind.

How do you know if your
employees and customers trust
you?

How do you know if they're
being honest about their lack
of trust in you?
Yeah.

So the good news here,
for better or worse,

is that people vote
with their feet.

So, trust is a willingness to
be vulnerable to other people's
actions and intentions.

So what that means is
that if I'm a customer,

I'm relying on companies for
their products and services.

And so if I wanted to
know whether or not

my customers trust me, I'd
look at customer retention

and see how I'm fairing
directly with that.

I'd look about NPS scores,
customers' willingness
to recommend you.

And that's a kind of a funny
tool, but to the extent

that it's used
well in a company,

you have some bead
on what it is.

And most of all, honestly,
from the standpoint of trust,

I'd look at whether people have
had problems with your company

and whether or not
they're still with you.

Because being able to
recover from a problem

is probably the
hallmark of trust.

I certainly knew, when I was
an executive at Fidelity,

people became more
loyal after they

had a problem with the company
and we were able to fix it.

And the same is generally
true, of course, with trust.

So for customers, there are
measures of these things
that you can look at.

And if your company doesn't
have measures to those three,

that's a place
where I would start.

I think, with respect to
employees, I'd probably ask--
and this is maybe unfair--

how are you doing with
the great resignation?
Yeah.
Right.

So there, I think
the question is,

we know that there are all kinds
of forces encouraging employees

to take advantage of this
kind of unique moment

in the labor market where
they have the upper hand.

And so the first thing I'd
look at as to whether or not

people trust me
is, how am I doing
on my voluntary terminations?
How many people are leaving?

And there, again, there
are processes in place.
We do exit interviews.

We do all kinds of things
to try to understand
why people do that.

If that were true, I would
double down right now

and really try to
understand what's

going on with my
employees and what
it is that's on their minds.

So you know, I think that
you could look at engagement

and also whether
employees recommend you
as a place to work.

But right now, I
think the focus should

be on who's staying,
who's leaving, and why.
Yeah.

So let's assume you've
done the research.

You know that you've
got a trust issue.
What should you do about it?

What can business leaders
do to regain the trust
that they've lost?
Yeah.

So there's a well-established
formula, believe it or not,
for restoring lost trust.

That's actually
really good news.
And it's got three steps to it.

So the first step is, you have
to acknowledge responsibility
and apologize.
All right.

So if you've done
something, that's step one.

Step two is, you have to
actually explain and try
to understand what went wrong.
Right.

People want to know that you
know what it is that you did,

and that you understand
what it is that you did.

And then, the third
step is what's
called an offer of repair.

And this is where you try
to dig in and say, OK,

if I did this thing
wrong, what is it

that I can do for you
to try to make you whole
and believe in my company again?

And so a great example of
this, they don't like usually

when I say this, is the
PricewaterhouseCoopers

and what they did
during the 2017 Oscars

when the wrong company got
the Best Picture award.

So to their credit,
literally that night,

there was an announcement up on
their website and PR releases

apologizing for what they did
wrong, explaining for the fact

that, inadvertently,
the wrong envelope had
been handed to the presenter.

And then, they spent
the next couple

of months working with
interviewing directly

the people who had
been affected by this,

and then working
with the Academy

to try to figure out what
protocols they should

put in place to guarantee that
this would never happen again.

So that's what trust
recovery looks like.

It's not mysterious, but it
does require intentionality,

and you have to say,
this is something
I'm trying to understand.
Yeah.

And I guess real self-reflection
on the part of the organization

to be able to say, we've got to
take a hard look at ourselves.
Absolutely.

And I think that that,
actually, is probably

the biggest foundation
of establishing

trusting relationships is
to understand that it really
is a relationship.

You are part of it, and the
other party's part of it.

And I think that the
companies that do this well,

they think all the time about
this question about, what

are we doing to make
this work, and what
is it that we could do more of?
Yeah.

Are there big missteps that
you can describe for us

that the business leaders
should be sure not
to make as they're doing this?

So they're doing it with
the right intention,

but, boy, we know that sometimes
good intentions come out badly.
Yeah.

So probably the biggest
misstep that the companies make

is thinking that
trust is a question
of managing your reputation.

Now, I'm the first person to
say reputations are important

and a very good thing, but
we know, from the research,

that trust is built
from the inside out.

It's really impossible to
build trust with your customers

if your employees don't
have trust in you.

And so I think the
biggest misstep

is not understanding
the origin of trust,

and where it sits, and the
role that you can play.

And this is probably good
news if you're a company.

This is something you actually
have some control over and can
really try to influence.

So that's the biggest
misstep is to think

that it's a problem on the
outside when it's actually
a problem on the inside.
Yeah.

This has been-- always
great talking with you.

These insights are
great, and I want
to thank you for sharing them.

I've got one more
question before we

let you go, which is,
for those business

leaders that are
listening to this

and watching this conversation,
what can they do today to get
started on rebuilding trust?

So I have one very
concrete suggestion,

and the suggestion
is, the next time

you have to make a big decision
or a substantial decision,

to ask yourself and
the people in the room,

will this action cause us to
build trust or to lose trust,
and with whom?

And so I think the trick here is
building the question of trust

into decision-making,
and making sure

that it's something that
you keep front and forward.

And because different
parties trust you

for different
reasons, some people

may trust you more
for something you do,
and others will trust you less.

And I think really
starting to look

at business decision-making
through this lens of,

who's gaining, who's
losing, and how am I

faring here, I think that will
actually really help keep trust
front and forward.
Great advice.

Sandra Sucher, thank you so
much for joining us on Managing
Through Crisis.
OK, great.
Thank you.
